body.p: The Council met. W. B. Machen President in the chair.
Josiah Pillsbury Auditor of State appeared and took the oath required by law.

The Council took up the bill entitled "An act for the benefit of common Schools and other purposes", the same having been made the special order of the day for 10 1/2 O'Clock A. M. to day --
Mr Crockett offered the following amendment viz:
"Insert after the words "thereof" in the 11th line of 2nd section these words "or accruing interest thereon"-
And the question being taken on said amendment, it was decided in the affirmative
And then the Council took a recess until 2 O'Clock P. M.
On motion the Council went into secret Session-

A Message from the Governor by R. McKee Secretary of State
Mr President: I am directed to lay before this Council a Special message in writing:

Executive Office
Bowling Green Ky
December 11th 1861
Honl. W. B. Machen President of the Council of the State of Kentucky

I herewith lay before the Council two despatches, received from
62
H. C. Burnett, one of our Commissioners at Richmond, by which the gratifying intelligence is communicated of the unanimous and unconditional admission of the state of Kentucky, into the Government of the Confederate States of America-

It is considered important by our Commissioner, that Kentucky should be represented in the provisional Congress of the Confederate States now in Session at Richmond. In this Opinion I concur, and recommend the appointment of a suitable number of Delegates to the Provisional Congress.
I also recommend the election of two senators, and provision by law for the election of members of the House of Representatives, in the Congress of the Confederate States of America

very Respectfully
Your Obt Servt..
George W. Johnson
The despatches referred to read as follows
Richmond Decr. 11.th 1861

Kentucky admitted -- injunction of secrecy removed -- appoint at once delegates to the Provisional Congress -- We need some one on the floor of the Congress now. Simms, Morris, Genl. Tom Johnson of Montgomery, Genl. Read and Judge Monroe are here- If you should appoint any of them, telegraph the fact so that they can take their seats

Richmond Dec.' 11th 1861
To George W. Johnson
Genl Thomas Johnson Ninth Kentucky Congressional District is here -- Kentuckians want his appointment to Congress -- answer to

On motion said message and accompanying documents were to a select Committee.
whereupon the President constituted said committee as follows-
Mess Crockett H. W. Bruce and P. B. Thompson, with instructions to report by bill or otherwise
There being no further business in Executive Session the Council resumed its general Session

The Council then resumed the consideration of the pending bill in reference to Common Schools.
63
Mr Thompson in the Chair.

Mr Machen moved to strike out all that portion of the bill relating to the jury fund
The question being taken on the motion to strike out, it was decided in the negative-
Mr Bates moved to recommit said bill to the Committee On Common Schools- and the question being taken thereon it was decided in the affirmative
And then the Council adjourned till 10 O'Clock A. M. tomorrow.

Attest
A Frank Brown Clerk
